questions.text: All of the following are the risk factors for development of colorectal cancer, except?
questions.solution:
Colorectal cancer risk factors include obesity (A), Streptococcus bovis infection (C), and Polyposis coli (D). Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits, but it is not considered a risk factor for colorectal cancer.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 637

questions.text:
IDENTIFY THE TRUE AND FALSE.
a)The liver and skeletal muscle together account for >50% of daily body protein turnover.
b) Skeletal muscle has a large mass but a low turnover rate (1-2% per day), whereas the liver has a relatively small mass (1.5 kg) but a much higher protein turnover rate (10-20% per day).
c) short- term changes in albumin concentration are most probably due to decreased synthesis.
d) Albumin TER may be increased threefold following major injury/sepsis
questions.solution:
The liver and skeletal muscle together account for >50% of daily body protein turnover.

Skeletal muscle has a large mass but a low turnover rate (1–2% per day), whereas the liver has a relatively small mass (1.5 kg) but a much higher protein turnover rate (10-20% per day).

Hepatic protein synthesis is divided roughly 50:50 between renewal of structural proteins and synthesis of export proteins. Albumin is the major export protein produced by the liver and is renewed at the rate of about 10% per day.

The transcapillary escape rate (TER) of albumin is about 10 times the rate of synthesis, and short- term changes in albumin concentration are most probably due to increased vascular permeability. Albumin TER may be increased threefold following major injury/sepsis.

In response to inflammatory conditions, including surgery, trauma and sepsis, pro infammatory cytokines, including IL-1, IL-6 and TNFα and in particular IL-6, promote the hepatic synthesis of positive acute-phase proteins, e.g. fibrinogen and C-reactive protein (CRP).

REF : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 7

questions.text: A 24 years old female came with 2 years of infertility and sub mucosal fibroids. She was scheduled for a myomectomy. All of the following measures reduce bleeding during myomectomy except:
questions.solution:
Measures to control blood loss during myomectomy

  • Preoperative GnRH analogs
  • Moderate degree of Trendelenberg position to enhance venous return
  • Timing the surgery in the immediate postmenstrual phase.
  • Hypotensive anaesthesia (using sodium nitro prudside)
  • Use of vasoconstrictive agents mainly vasopressin intraoperatively
  • Use of victor Bonney’s myomectomy clamp around blood vessels and round ligament
  • Use of tourniquets around blood vessels
  • Uterine artery embolisation (UAE)

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics - 6th edition - Page no604.

questions.text: Patellar tendon bearing P.O.P. cast is indicated in the following fracture
questions.solution:
Nonoperative treatment of tibia shaft fractures is typically performed with either cast immobilization or functional bracing. Both treatment methods involve initial stabilization in a long leg cast or a well-molded splint for 2 to 4 weeks until the soft tissue swelling reduces and callus formation begins. The long leg splint is then changed to a short leg patellar tendon-bearing (PTB) cast or a fabricated functional brace. The advantage of a functional brace over a PTB cast is that it allows ankle motion in addition to knee motion.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no: 4344

questions.text: Match the Gastric ulcer type according to the ulcer site?
questions.solution:
GUs have been classified based on their location:

  • Type I occur in the gastric body and tend to be associated with low gastric acid production;
  • Type II occur in the antrum, and gastric acid can vary from low to normal;
  • Type III occur within 3 cm of the pylorus and are commonly accompanied by DUs and normal or high gastric acid production; and
  • Type IV are found in the cardia and are associated with low gastric acid production.

questions.text: For treatment of anal incontinence, SACRAL NERVE STIMULATION is a novel technique that uses low voltage electrical stimulation to the ................nerve roots to augment continence.
questions.solution:
Sacral nerve stimulation (SNS) is a novel tech- nique that uses low-voltage electrical stimulation to the S3 or S4 nerve roots to augment continence .It is thought to work primarily by activation of autonomic sensory pathways in patients with pelvic neuropathy, which principally occurs after childbirth. The technique consists of a screening phase of peripheral nerve evaluation, followed by a therapeutic phase of permanent neurostimulator implantation (Matzel).

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1426

questions.text: Smt. Pushpa is a suspected case of ovarian tumors. On laparotomy bilaterally enlarged ovaries with smooth surface was seen:
questions.solution:
Krukenberg tumor:

  • Krukenberg tumor by definition represents carcinoma of stomach metastasised to ovary. But the eponym is commonly used to denote any gastric cancer metastatic to ovary
  • Tumour arise by retrograde lymphatic spread i.e. carcinoma cells pass from the stomach to the superior gastric lymph node which also receives lymphatics from the ovary.

Characteristics of Krukenberg Tumour:

  1. Always bilateral
  2. Have smooth surface
  3. No tendency to form adhesions
  4. Freely mobile
  5. No infiltration through the capsule.
  6. Histologically the tumour has signet ring cells in the background of myxomatous stroma.
  7. They retain the shape of a normal ovary.
  8. Have waxy consistency.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 15th Edition - Page no 425-6

questions.text: Correct sequence for stages of normal wound healing_________
questions.solution:
Classically, wound healing has been arbitrarily described in three overlapping but distinct stages, including inflammation, proliferation and remodeling.

Haemostasis: This is the initial stage of wound healing and involves the cessation of bleeding. Blood vessels constrict and platelets form clots to stop the bleeding.

Inflammation: After haemostasis, the body initiates an inflammatory response to clear debris and prevent infection. Inflammation involves the recruitment of immune cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages, to the wound site.

Proliferation: During this stage, new tissue is built to repair the wound. Fibroblasts produce collagen, blood vessels are formed (angiogenesis), and epithelial cells migrate to cover the wound.

Remodeling: In the final stage, the newly formed tissue undergoes remodeling. Collagen is reorganized and strengthened, and the scar tissue gradually matures. This phase can last for an extended period, often several months to a year or more.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 24 , 25

questions.text: A 10-day old baby comes with increasing tachypnea and respiratory difficulty, not feeding well. The X ray is as shown below. Which of the following is strongly suspected?
questions.solution:
• Congenital lobar emphysema- This uncommon condition is due to bronchial obstruction or deficiency of bronchial cartilage. It is characterized by overinflation of one or more lobes. It is usually unilateral and the left upper and right middle lobe are the most affected.
  • Presentation can be with respiratory distress soon after birth and wheezes. CT lung scan helps to confirm the diagnosis. Bronchoscopy is occasionally performed if a removable cause of bronchial obstruction is found. Sometimes surgical excision of the affected lobe is required, but conservative management is often effective.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2051

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient had complaints of gradual onset weakness on leg since 2 months with reduction in visual acuity and urinary incontinence since 7 days .MRI Brain shows hyperintensity in periventricular lesion.CSF oligoclonal band positive.Which of the following drug is used in these patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation with gradual onset weakness, reduced visual acuity, urinary incontinence, and MRI brain findings of hyperintensity in periventricular lesions suggests a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS).

Interferon Beta is a disease-modifying therapy commonly used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis. It helps to reduce the frequency and severity of relapses, slow down the progression of the disease, and alleviate some of the symptoms associated with MS. Oligoclonal bands in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are often seen in MS patients and support the diagnosis.

Interferon Alpha and Interferon Gamma are not typically used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis

Infliximab is a medication used to treat inflammatory conditions like Crohn's disease and rheumatoid arthritis but is not a first-line treatment for multiple sclerosis. Interferon Beta is a more common choice for MS management.

Reference- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 3467,3470

questions.text: A patient had a spontaneous abortion, then she came with amenorrhea and FSH 6 pm IU/mL. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Normal FSH values range from 5 to 20 mzU/mL. in the question, FSH levels are 6 mzU/mL, that means this is a case of secondary amenorrhea with normal FSH values.
    • In case of pituitary failure - as is evident from the flow diagram ® values of FSH should be lower than the normal values. So Option 'd' is ruled out
    • Incase of ovarian failure → estrogen is deficient so negative feedback on FSH will be absent, thus values of FSH will be more than normal. In case of ovarian failure/menopause, FSH is above 40 m IU/mL so option a is also ruled out.
  2. Normal FSH and amenorrhea point towards uterine The patient had a spontaneous abortion following which a curettage is generally required which would be responsible for intrauterine synechiae (Asherman's Syndrome). Thus, the most probable diagnosis is uterine synechiae.

Reference. DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics - 6th edition - Page no415-425.

questions.text: THE SEPSIS BUNDLE also known as the resuscitation bundle, is a combination of evidence based objectives that must be completed within ______ hrs for patients presenting with severe septic shock and /or lactate > _______ mmol/l.
questions.solution:
The sepsis bundle, also known as the resuscitation bundle, is a combination of evidence-based objectives that must be completed within 6 hours for patients presenting with severe sepsis, septic shock and/or lactate >4 mmol/L.

The Sepsis Six is the name given to a bundle of medical therapies designed to reduce mortality in patients with sepsis. Drawn from international guidelines that emerged from the Surviving Sepsis Campaign, the Sepsis Six was developed by the UK's Sepsis Trust. The components of the Sepsis Six are:

  • give three to patients:
    1. intravenous fluid challenge,
    2. intravenous antibiotics,
    3. oxygen and monitor urine output;
  • take three from patients:
    1. blood cultures,
    2. full blood count,
    3. lactate.

Reference : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 59

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient had a breakup with his girlfriend one day ago.After that he ingested 30 tablets of paracetamol.He was taken by his relative to hospital with altered sensorium.What is false statement regarding Paracetamol poisoning?
questions.solution:
Acetaminophen causes dose-related centrilobular hepatic necrosis after single-time-point ingestions, as intentional self-harm, or over extended periods, as unintentional overdoses, when multiple drug preparations or inappropriate drug amounts are used daily for several days, for example, for relief of pain or fever. In these instances, 8 g/d, twice the daily recommended maximum dose, over several days can readily lead to liver failure.

A single dose of 10-15 g, occasionally less, may produce clinical evidence of liver injury. Fatal fulminant disease is usually (although not invariably) associated with ingestion of ≥25 g.

Blood levels of acetaminophen correlate with severity of hepatic injury (levels >300 μg/mL 4 h after ingestion are predictive of the development of severe damage; levels <150 μg/mL suggest that hepatic injury is highly unlikely).

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and shock are early manifestations occurring 4-12 h after ingestion. Then 24-48 h later, when these features are abating, hepatic injury becomes apparent.

Maximal abnormalities and hepatic failure are evident 3-5 days after ingestion, and aminotransferase levels exceeding 10,000 IU/L are not uncommon (i.e., levels far exceeding those in patients with viral hepatitis). Renal failure and myocardial injury may be present.

Whether or not a clear history of overdose can be elicited, clinical suspicion of acetaminophen hepatotoxicity should be raised by the presence of the extremely high aminotransferase levels in association with low bilirubin levels that are characteristic of this hyperacute injury.

This biochemical signature should trigger further questioning of the subject if possible; however, outright denial (or denial of high doses) or altered mentation may confound diagnostic efforts.

In this setting, a presumptive diagnosis is reasonable, and the proven antidote, N-acetylcysteine, is both safe and will be effective if given early (within 12 h) but is also used even when injury has evolved.

Reference. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2588

questions.text: A 38 year old female patient is a known case of Rheumatoid arthritis since 10 years on irregular treatment.She had developed Felty syndrome.All are the following are components of this syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Felty's syndrome is defined by the clinical triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular RA and is seen in <1% of patients, although its incidence appears to be declining in the face of more aggressive treatment of the joint disease.

It typically occurs in the late stages of severe RA and is more common in whites than other racial groups.

T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia (T-LGL) may have a similar clinical presentation and often occurs in association with RA.

T-LGL is characterized by a chronic, indolent clonal growth of LGL cells, leading to neutropenia and splenomegaly.

As opposed to Felty's syndrome, T-LGL may develop early in the course of RA.

Leukopenia apart from these disorders is uncommon and most often a side effect of drug therapy.

Reference. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2753

questions.text: The ideal time and place for hair removal before surgery ?
questions.solution:
Timing of hair removal

The ideal time and place for hair removal is on the operating table after a dose of prophylactic antibiotic is given. Preopera- tive removal of hair outside the confines of the operating room is discouraged.

Method of hair removal

Skin clippers with disposable blades are preferred as they are safe and result in the fewest SSIs. Shaving using a razor blade is discouraged as unintended micro incisions caused by the blade often result in exaggerated skin infection and inflammation.

Reference :Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 96 , 97

questions.text: In heart patient the worst prognosis during pregnancy is seen in:
questions.solution:
In pregnant women with pre-existing heart disease, the prognosis varies depending on the type and severity of the heart condition. Aortic stenosis (option c) is associated with one of the worst prognosis during pregnancy among the given options.

Aortic stenosis is a condition where the aortic valve, which controls blood flow from the heart into the aorta (the main artery that carries oxygenated blood to the body), is narrowed or obstructed. During pregnancy, the increased blood volume and cardiac output can place additional stress on the heart. In cases of severe aortic stenosis, this increased workload can lead to heart failure and poor outcomes for both the mother and the baby.

Reference. Williams Obstetrics 23rd Edition - Page no 1026, 1027, 1030

Reference. Williams Obstetrics 23rd Edition - Page no 968

questions.text: Which schizophrenia subtype responds poorly to 1st generation antipsychotics?
questions.solution:
Simple schizophrenia has a poor prognosis and is associated with a poorer response to 1st generation antipsychotics.

Simple schizophrenia is a subtype of schizophrenia characterized by a gradual and insidious decline in personality, social functioning, and overall life skills. It typically has a poor prognosis and tends to respond poorly to treatment with first-generation (typical) antipsychotic medications. Individuals with simple schizophrenia often require long-term care and support.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition - Page no 965

questions.text: Which of the following structures is protected from carcinoid syndrome due to degradation of mediators?
questions.solution:

The left side of the heart is afforded some measure of protection because the pulmonary vascular bed degrades the mediators.

questions.text: Based on the mechanism of action provided in the below image, which drug acts at this site marked as A in the structure of the tuberculosis bacterium?
questions.solution:
Ethambutol (E)

Ethambutol, a synthetic straight-chain compound, is selectively tuberculostatic and is active against MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex) as well as some other mycobacteria, but not other types of bacteria. Fast multiplying bacilli are more susceptible.

The mechanism of action of ethambutol is not fully understood, but it has been found to inhibit arabinosyl transferases (encoded by the embA and embB genes) involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid incorporation in the mycobacterial cell wall. Resistance to ethambutol develops slowly and is most commonly associated with mutations in the embB gene, reducing the affinity of the target enzyme for ethambutol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p819

questions.text: Identify the organism growing in the given image:
questions.solution:
Yersinia pestis has a typical growth characteristic called stalactite-like growth.

It grows in clumps that are typically described as flocculant or stalactite-like in appearance when the broth culture is not shaken or mixed.

At 24 hours growth is seen as clumps that hang along the side of the tube. After 24 hours the growth settles to the bottom of the tube and is described as cotton fluff.

Mostly, this type of stalactite growth occurs on ghee broth.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no354

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient had complaints of breathlessness on exertion, high grade fever and dry cough for 2 days. She turns out to be COVID-19 positive. Later she worsened and required ventilatory support within 1 day. A CXR was taken and is shown below.What is false regarding the ventilatory management in this patient?
questions.solution:
1. Neuromuscular blockade: In some severe cases of COVID-19-related ARDS, neuromuscular blockade with medications like cisatracurium may be used to improve oxygenation and lung compliance. It can help reduce patient-ventilator dyssynchrony and prevent self-inflicted lung injury.
  2. Prone positioning: Prone positioning involves placing the patient face down, and it is a recommended intervention for severe ARDS, including COVID-19-related ARDS. Prone positioning helps improve oxygenation and ventilation by redistributing ventilation to the less affected lung regions and reducing the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI).
  3. High tidal volume: High tidal volumes should be avoided in ARDS, including COVID-19-related ARDS. Low tidal volume ventilation (around 6 mL/kg of predicted body weight) is the standard of care to prevent VILI and reduce the risk of barotrauma.
  4. High PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): The use of high PEEP levels is common in ARDS management, including COVID-19-related ARDS. High PEEP helps keep the alveoli open, improves oxygenation, and reduces atelectasis. It can be an important part of lung-protective ventilation strategies.

Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2228

questions.text: Approximately 90 % of the GASTRINOMA occurs within the gastrinoma triangle. All are the boundaries of the gastrinoma triangle except________
questions.solution:
In sporadic disease the tumours are mostly located in the duodenum (60-80%) and are small (<5 mm) and multiple. In MEN 1, all tumours are in the duodenum. The vast majority (approximately 90%) occur within the 'gastrinoma triangle', an area bounded by the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas medially, the junction of the second and third parts of the duodenum inferiorly and the junction of the cystic and common bile ducts superiorly (Figure 57.15). Tumours are graded according to WHO NET criteria (Table 57.5). In general, the progression of gastrinomas is relatively slow with a 5-year survival rate of 65% and a 10-year survival rate of 51%. Patients with complete tumour resection have excellent 5- and 10-year survival rates (90-100%). Patients with pancre- atic tumours have a worse prognosis than those with primary tumours in the duodenum. There is no established marker to predict the biological behaviour of gastrinoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 907

questions.text: Acalculous cholecystitis may be caused by which of the following organism:
questions.solution:
ACALCULOUS CHOLECYSTITIS In 5-14% of patients with acute cholecystitis, calculi obstructing the cystic duct are not found at surgery.

In >50% of such cases, an underlying explanation for acalculous inflammation is not found. An increased risk for the development of acalculous cholecystitis is especially associated with prolonged fasting, with serious trauma or burns, in the postpartum period following prolonged labor, and with orthopedic and other non biliary major surgical operations in the postoperative period.

It may possibly complicate periods of prolonged parenteral hyperalimentation. For some of these cases, biliary sludge in the cystic duct may be responsible.

Other precipitating factors include vasculitis, obstructing adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder, diabetes mellitus, torsion of the gallbladder, 'unusual' bacterial infections of the gallbladder (e.g., Leptospira, Streptococcus, Salmonella, or Vibrio cholerae), and parasitic infestation of the gallbladder.

Acalculous cholecystitis may also be seen with a variety of other systemic disease processes (e.g., sarcoidosis, cardiovascular disease, tuberculosis, syphilis, actinomycosis)

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2649

choices.text: Suspicious lesion on the chest radiograph in which neoplasia cannot be excluded

questions.text: Which of the following are the indications for surgery in lung tuberculosis
questions.solution:
While surgery may be indicated in certain cases of tuberculosis of the lung, not all of the provided options are considered standard indications for surgery:

A) A suspicious lesion on the chest radiograph in which neoplasia cannot be excluded may require surgery for diagnostic purposes to rule out lung cancer or other malignancies.

B) Tuberculous abscesses that are sensitive to chemotherapy are typically managed with medical treatment, and surgery is not a standard first-line approach for these cases.

C) Miliary tuberculosis is a disseminated form of tuberculosis that usually requires medical treatment, and surgery is not typically indicated.

So, the primary indication for surgery in tuberculosis of the lung among the options provided is the suspicion of neoplasia (lung cancer) when it cannot be excluded based on radiographic findings.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 994

questions.text: A 44-year-old female complains of lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. On examination, there is cervicitis along with a mucopurulent cervical discharge. The Gram smear of the discharge shows presence of abundant pus cells, but no bacteria. The best approach to isolate the possible causative agent would be:
questions.solution:
• Patient is complaining of abdominal pain and vaginal discharge.
  • On examination, cervicitis and mucopurulent discharge is seen-which indicates she is having PID.
  • The presence of pus cells in the absence of an organism indicates chlamydial infection (most common STD today).
  • It is an intracellular organism that grows only on McCoy or HeLa cell cultures. It cannot be grown on other media and hence, often goes unnoticed, later leading to infertility.
  • Culture in Mc Coy cells is 100% specific for chlamydia but is inexpensive, technically difficult and takes 3-7 days to obtain the result.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 18th Edition - Page 1426.

choices.text: Anterior external fixation with pelvic packing

questions.text: Given below is the pelvic radiograph from a 33-year-old man involved in a high-speed automobile crash. Examination reveals a blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 120/min. Radiographs of the chest and lateral cervical spine are normal. A CT scan of the abdomen does not reveal any intra-abdominal bleeding. What is the most appropriate management for the pelvic fracture?
questions.solution:
Because the patient has not had any mechanical stabilization to the pelvic ring, the first step in management should be application of a sheet or binder along with resuscitation. Pelvic binders have been shown to be effective in decreasing transfusion needs and are quick and simple to apply.

Emergent external fixation, pelvic packing, or angiography is not indicated unless the patient is unresponsive to these initial measures. The order in which these measures are used is controversial and somewhat institution dependent. Repair of the pubic symphysis is indicated as part of the definitive treatment but should not be done prior to resuscitation with pelvic binder placement.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no: 942

questions.text: According to BOSNIAK CLASSIFICATION of renal cyst, which type is shown below ?
questions.solution:
The Bosniak classification is a system used to categorize renal cysts based on their imaging characteristics, primarily using contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The classification helps in assessing the likelihood of malignancy and guides the management of renal cystic lesions.

Bosniak I: Simple cysts with a thin wall and no internal septations, calcifications, or solid components. They are considered benign and require no further evaluation.

Bosniak II: Cysts with a few thin septations or fine calcifications. These are typically benign but may require periodic imaging for monitoring.

Bosniak IIF: Cysts with more numerous or thicker septations, some of which may be enhanced on contrast imaging. These have a slightly higher risk of malignancy and may require closer follow-up or evaluation.

Bosniak III: Cysts with thickened irregular walls, thick septations, or enhancing solid components. These are more suspicious for malignancy and often warrant surgical evaluation or biopsy.

Bosniak IV: Cysts with enhancing solid components that are highly suspicious for malignancy. Surgical intervention or biopsy is often necessary for diagnosis and treatment.

Reference : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1461

questions.text: What is the ideal treatment for a 55-years-female with Simple hyperplasia of endometrium with Atypia?
questions.solution:
Management of Atypical Endometrial Hyperplasia:

"Hysterectomy is the best treatment for women at any age with atypical endometrial hyperplasia because the risk of concurrent subclinical invasive disease is high."

"In presence of atypia, response to progesterone therapy is poor and relapse rate is high. Nearly one-third of them will progress to cancer and one-fourth may already have associated undiagnosed cancer. In women approaching or past menopause, hysterectomy is a safer choice in those with complex or atypical hyperplasia."

Best management of atypical hyperplasia is hysterectomy. Also Know: Management of Endometrial Hyperplasia:

Management depends on the patient’s age and the presence or absence of cytological atypia.

  • Non atypical hyperplasia:
    • Premenopausal women:
      • Progesterone therapy
        • Options:
          • Medroxyprogesterone acetate for 21 days a month daily for 3 months.
          • Progesterone containing IUCD.
    • Postmenopausal women
      • Simple hyperplasia without atypia
        • Generally followed without therapy.
      • Complex hyperplasia without atypia
        • Cyclical/continous progesterone therapy.
        • These patients should be followed annually by endometrial biopsy.
  • Atypical hyperplasia:
    • Ideal treatment is hysterectomy
    • Premenopausal women willing to preserve fertility – High dose progesterone therapy after full information of risk of an undiagnosed cancer or progression to cancer. In these cases, periodic TVS and endometrial biopsy is necessary.

questions.text:
Consider the following statement regarding classic polyarteritis nodosa:
I. It is multisystem necrotizing vasculitis
II. Small and medium vessels are involved
III. Pulmonary artery involvement is a characteristic features
IV. Upto 30% patient may show positive test for Hepatitis B surface antigen
Which of these statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa is a multisystem, necrotizing vasculitis of small- and medium-sized muscular arteries in which involvement of the renal and visceral arteries is characteristic.

Polyarteritis nodosa does not involve pulmonary arteries, although bronchial vessels may be involved; granulomas, significant eosinophilia, and an allergic diathesis are not observed.

There are no diagnostic serologic tests for polyarteritis nodosa. In >75% of patients, the leukocyte count is elevated with a predominance of neutrophils. Eosinophilia is seen only rarely and, when present at high levels, suggests the diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss). The anemia of chronic disease may be seen, and an elevated ESR and/or CRP is almost always present.

Other common laboratory findings reflect the particular organ involved.Hypergammaglobulinemia may be present, and all patients should be screened for hepatitis B and C.

ANCA are rarely found in patients with polyarteritis nodosa.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2811

questions.text: TERSON SYNDROME is________
questions.solution:
The combination of SAH and vitreous hemorrhage is known as Terson's syndrome and occurs in 15-20% of patients. Papil- loedema should be sought, but may not be evident early in the course of a developing hydrocephalus.

Terson syndrome is a medical condition characterized by the presence of intraocular bleeding (vitreous hemorrhage) in conjunction with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), typically due to a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or head injury. The combination of SAH and vitreous hemorrhage is known as Terson syndrome, and it is an important clinical finding to recognize in patients with SAH.

questions.text: Patient is diagnosed with vaginal carcinoma. By doing various investigations, doctors came to know that the pelvis has already been involved. Involvement of pelvis in a case of vaginal carcinoma of stage:
questions.solution:
Vaginal carcinoma is staged based on the extent of the tumor's spread. The pelvis involvement in vaginal carcinoma corresponds to stage IV. In the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) staging system for vaginal carcinoma, stage IV indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the vaginal walls. In this stage, the tumor has typically invaded nearby pelvic structures, such as the bladder or rectum, or it may have metastasized to distant organs. Stage IV represents an advanced and often more challenging stage of vaginal cancer, and treatment approaches may involve a combination of surgery, radiation therapy, and sometimes chemotherapy, depending on the extent of the disease.

Minor criteria

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1P0 at 35 weeks gestation presents with several days H/O generalised malaise, anorexia, nausea, emesis and abdominal discomfort. On exertion she is mild jaundiced and little confused. Her temp is 100 degree F, PR-70, BP-100/62, no significant edema, appears dehydrated. FHR is 160 and is nonreactive but with good variability. Her WBC- 25000, Hct- 42.0, platelets- 51000, SGOT/SGPT- 287/350, GLUCOSE-43, Creatinine- 2.0, fibrinogen- 135, PT/PTT- 16/50, S. Ammonia level- 90 m mol/L. Urine is 3+ proteins with large amount of ketones. What is the recommend treatment for this patient
questions.solution:
This is not HELLP syndrome as her B/P is normal and not raised.

In AFP: Termination of pregnancy is the first step as spontaneous resolution usually follows delivery.

'The key to a good outcome is intensive supportive care and good obstetrical management. Spontaneous resolution usually follows delivery. In some cases, the fetus may be already dead when the diagnosis is made, and the route of delivery is less problematic. Many viable fetuses tolerate labor poorly. Because significant procrastination in effecting delivery may increase maternal and fetal risks, we prefer a trial of labor induction with close fetal surveillance. Although some recommend cesarean delivery to hasten hepatic healing, this increases maternal risk when there is a severe coagulopathy. Transfusions with whole blood or packed red cells, along with fresh-frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate, and platelets, are usually necessary if surgery is performed or if obstetric lacerations complicated vaginal delivery.'

questions.text: Symptoms of intermittent postnasal discharge and odynophagia combined with a dull occipital headache would be most likely to occur in the presence of a
questions.solution:
Symptoms of Thornwaldt's cysts include intermittent or persistent postnasal discharge of tenacious mucus associated with odynophagia, halitosis, unpleasant taste, and, occasionally, a dull occipital headache. The closest possible potential choice is Rathke's cyst. Rathke's cysts are not usually associated with postnasal discharge or headache. However, they can become secondarily infected or rupture intracranially producing galactorrhea, visual loss, and hypopituitarism. Unilateral choanal atresia is an unlikely distracter, and although teratomas and craniopharyngiomas arise in the nasopharyngeal region, they are not commonly associated with headache or intermittent postnasal discharge.

Sterno mental distance of SAUVA test measured from maintaining stern to chin. Normal value is more than 12.5 cm. This is considered as the single most important predictor of a difficult airway.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for status asthmaticus. She rapidly deteriorates and dies of her disease. All of the following pathologic findings would likely be seen in this individual EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The pathology of asthma has largely been determined by examining bronchial biopsies of patients with asthma as well as the lungs of individuals who die from asthma.

These pathologic changes are centered around the airways with sparing of the alveolar spaces.

The airways are infiltrated by eosinophils, activated T lymphocytes, and activated mucosal mast cells. However, the degree of inflammation does not correlate with the severity of asthma.

Another common finding in all asthmatics and individuals with eosinophilic bronchitis is thickening of the basement membrane due to collagen deposition in the subepithelium.

The airway smooth muscle is hypertrophied as well.

Overall, this leads to thickening of the airway wall, which may also exhibit edematous fluid, particularly in those with fatal asthma.

In cases of fatal asthma, it is also common to find multiple airways that are occluded by mucus plugs. However, the disease is limited to the airways, and infiltration of the alveolar spaces by inflammatory cells is not seen.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2150

questions.text: Which of the following is the site for erythropoiesis at the 8th month of gestation?
questions.solution:
• By 6-8 wk of gestation the liver replaces the yolk sac as the primary site of blood cell production, and during this time the placenta also contributes as a hematopoietic site.
  • By 10-12 wk extraembryonic hematopoiesis has essentially ceased. Hepatic hematopoiesis occurs through the remainder of gestation, although hepatic production diminishes during the second trimester while bone marrow (myeloid) hematopoiesis increases.
  • The liver remains the predominant erythropoietic organ (few if any neutrophils are produced in the human fetal liver) through 20-24 wk of gestation. After that bone marrow takes over the predominant function of hematopoiesis.

questions.text: A preterm neonate is taken up for Surgery for bilateral choanal atresia. Which ASA-PS class does the patient come under ?
questions.solution:
Neonates are obligate nasal breathers. A bilateral choanal atresia is an emergency condition, causing respiratory obstruction.

ASA I (Class 1): This classification represents a normal healthy patient without any systemic disease. It does not apply to a preterm neonate with a congenital condition like bilateral choanal atresia.

ASA III (Class III): This classification typically describes a patient with severe systemic disease. While a preterm neonate does have certain vulnerabilities and is not a "normal" healthy patient, they do not usually have severe systemic diseases at birth.

ASA IV (Class IV): This classification is reserved for patients with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life. Again, this classification doesn't typically apply to preterm neonates with choanal atresia.

ASA III E (Class III E): ASA class III E is used for patients with severe systemic disease that is not a constant threat to life. In the case of a preterm neonate with bilateral choanal atresia, while it is an emergency situation, the underlying condition itself (choanal atresia) doesn't necessarily represent a constant threat to life once appropriate medical intervention is provided.

Reference: Oxford’s handbook of anaesthesia, edition 4 , page no 1220

The associations typically seen with Type I MPGN include:

  • Hepatitis C (choice B): This is one of the most common associations with Type I MPGN.
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (choice A): MPGN can occur in the setting of autoimmune diseases like SLE.
  • Malignancy (choice D): Although less common than hepatitis C, malignancies can be associated with Type I MPGN, especially hematologic malignancies.
  • ACE inhibitors are not a known common cause or association with Type I MPGN.

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetic is used as a part of tumescent anesthesia

questions.text: All are true about the investigation of chest injuries except________
questions.solution:
When evaluating chest injuries, various diagnostic modalities may be employed depending on the clinical situation. The statement that "A CT SCAN of the chest is the investigation of first choice" is not universally accurate. While CT scans are valuable for assessing chest injuries, their use may depend on factors such as patient stability, availability of resources, and specific clinical indications. Initial evaluation often begins with clinical assessment, basic imaging (such as X-rays), and physical examination. CT scans may follow if more detailed information is needed. Therefore, it cannot be unequivocally stated that CT scans are the first-choice investigation in all cases of chest injuries.

REF : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 373

questions.text: A case of 35-week pregnancy with hydramnios and marked respiratory distress is best treated by:
questions.solution:
The patient in the question has marked respiratory distress (i.e. it is a severe polyhydramnios and requires treatment) and gestational age is 35 weeks (i.e., fetal maturity is not yet achieved).

So our aim should be to relieve the distress of patients in hope of continuing the pregnancy till at least 37 weeks.

This can be achieved by:

  • Amniocentesis or
  • Use of Indomethacin

Amniocentesis:

  • The main aim of amniocentesis is to relieve maternal distress with the added advantage that lung maturity of fetus can be predicted by Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio in the expressed fluid.
  • Slow decompression is done at the rate of 500 ml/hr.
  • Maximum fluid removed is 1.5 - 2 liters.

Use of Indomethacin -Indomethacin should not be used in pregnancy more than 32 weeks because it leads to premature closure of ductus arteriosus.

Amniotomy: The main disadvantage of amniotomy is the possibility of cord prolapse and placental abruption. Slow removal of fluid by amniocentesis helps to obviate these dangers.

Ref - Williams Obstetrics 22nd Edition - Page no 530, 23/e, p 495

questions.text: AXILLARY VEIN THROMBOSIS is known as________
questions.solution:
AXILLARY VEIN THROMBOSIS

Thrombosis of the axillary vein (Paget-Schrotter disease) may occur following excessive exercise in a patient with an anatomically abnormal thoracic outlet, but is also associated with excessive muscle bulk as found in weight lifters. The vein may be compressed by a cervical rib if this is present. The arm is swollen and painful and, at an early stage, the thrombus can be disrupted by thrombolysis delivered through one of the arm veins. The vein must then be imaged to see if there is any compression on elevation of the arm. If this is confirmed, thoracic outlet decompression can be carried out by resecting the cervical rib or first rib.

REF : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1047, 1048

questions.text: Which type of achalasia may be better treated with long myotomy by POEM?
questions.solution:
POEM (Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy) is a minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat achalasia, a disorder that affects the esophagus and impairs its ability to move food into the stomach. Achalasia can be categorized into different types based on manometric findings.

Type III achalasia is characterized by spastic contractions and aperistalsis (ineffective contractions) in the esophagus. This type typically presents with more severe and diffuse symptoms than other types of achalasia.

Long myotomy by POEM is often considered an effective treatment option for Type III achalasia because it involves a longer esophageal myotomy to help relieve the spastic contractions and improve esophageal function. This procedure can be particularly beneficial for Type III achalasia patients who do not respond well to other treatments.

REF : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1125

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes has recently started peritoneal dialysis due to kidney disease from diabetic nephropathy. Which complications of peritoneal dialysis are of concern for this patient?
questions.solution:
Peritoneal dialysis is associated with a variety of metabolic complications.

Albumin and other proteins can be lost across the peritoneal membrane in concert with the loss of metabolic wastes.

Hypoproteinemia obligates a higher dietary protein intake to maintain nitrogen balance.

Hyperglycemia and weight gain are also common complications of peritoneal dialysis. Several hundred calories in the form of dextrose are absorbed each day, depending on the concentration of dextrose employed.

Patients receiving peritoneal dialysis, particularly those with diabetes mellitus, are prone to other complications of insulin resistance, including hypertriglyceridemia.

On the positive side, the continuous nature of peritoneal dialysis usually allows for a more liberal diet, due to continuous removal of potassium and phosphorus - two major dietary components whose accumulation can be hazardous in end-stage renal disease.

Ref. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2324

questions.text: Ulcer with PUNCHED OUT edges and thin base which may be covered with a wash leather slough is seen in_________
questions.solution:
The description of an ulcer with punched-out edges and a thin base, sometimes covered with a wash-leather-like slough, is characteristic of syphilitic ulcers. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. One of its manifestations is the development of syphilitic ulcers, also known as chancres, which have a distinctive appearance.

Ref : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 663

questions.text:
A 50 year old male patient is known case of glucagonoma develops skin lesion shown in below image.

identify the lesion
questions.solution:
Patients with glucagonoma most commonly present with a characteristic dermatitis, called necrolytic migratory erythema.

The rash usually involves intertriginous sites, especially in the groin or buttock, and can wax and wane. Other common presenting symptoms of glucagonoma include glucose intolerance and weight loss.

The diagnosis of glucagonoma can be confirmed by demonstrating an increased plasma glucagon level, generally in excess of 1000 pg/mL.

Somatostatin analogues are usually highly effective as an initial treatment to alleviate the symptoms and rash associated with glucagon hypersecretion. The majority of glucagonomas are large in size at presentation and arise in the tail of the pancreas.

For patients with localized disease, distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy are recommended. A hypercoagulable state has been reported in up to 33% of patients with glucagonoma, and perioperative anticoagulation should generally be employed.

Ref - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 665

choices.text: Vital signs stable for at least 1 hour
Correct orientation as to time, place and person if appropriate

questions.text: All are the discharge criteria for day care surgery except
questions.solution:
Discharge criteria for day care or ambulatory surgery are essential to ensure that patients are safe to go home after their procedure. Criteria typically include:

  • Vital signs stable for at least 1 hour (A)
  • Correct orientation as to time, place, and person if appropriate (B)
  • Minimal nausea, vomiting, or dizziness (D)

However, the requirement for "adequate pain control with the supply of injectable analgesia" (C) is not a typical discharge criterion. While pain management is crucial, it is usually assessed and managed before discharge, but the specific provision of injectable analgesia at home is not a standard criterion.

Ref : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 303

choices.text: Almost exclusively occurs in resource-poor countries and is due to malnutrition; alcohol is important cause
A low incidence of pancreatic cancer in those affected by the disease
Cassava ingestion is regarded as an etiological factor because of its low content of cyanide compounds
ERCP should be used as an investigation only when combined with a therapeutic procedure

questions.text:
A 20 yrs old male patient, from south India, from poor socioeconomic class presented with abdominal pain, thirst, polyuria, steatorrhoea and malnutrition. His x- ray abdomen is given.

All are false about this condition except________
questions.solution:
The condition being described here is Chronic Pancreatitis.

The other statements are true about chronic pancreatitis:

  1. A) Almost exclusively occurs in resource-poor countries and is due to malnutrition; alcohol is an important cause. Chronic pancreatitis can occur in both resource-poor and resource-rich countries. While malnutrition can be a contributing factor, alcohol consumption is a significant cause of chronic pancreatitis.
  2. B) A low incidence of pancreatic cancer in those affected by the disease. Chronic pancreatitis is associated with an increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer, so there is not a low incidence of pancreatic cancer in those with chronic pancreatitis.
  3. C) Cassava ingestion is regarded as an etiological factor because of its low content of cyanide compounds. Cassava ingestion, particularly when poorly processed, can be associated with cyanide exposure and is considered a potential etiological factor for chronic pancreatitis in some regions, but it is not the only cause of the disease.

ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) can be used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in the management of chronic pancreatitis, not solely as an investigation. Therapeutic interventions can include procedures such as stent placement or dilation of strictures in the pancreatic duct.

REF : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 86

questions.text: A child is able to draw a man with a head and 4 other body parts. According to the Goodenough Draw a man test, what is the developmental age of the child?
questions.solution:
• Goodenough Draw a man test, is used to assess development age between 3-10 years.
  • A 3-year-old child is able to draw a circle and hence a head. The score begins with 3.
  • For 4 additional body parts drawn besides the head, 1 year is added. Age= 3+ (n/4)
  • Hence for the child in the question, developmental age= 3 + (4/4)= 4 years.

(Ref. Illingworth The development of infant and young child, 10th ed., pg. 282)

choices.text: The a wave is not present with atrial fibrillation
The internal jugular vein is preferred for JVP tracing
The c wave, which occurs as the closed tricuspid valve is pushed into the right atrium during early ventricular diastole
The a wave represents right atrial presystolic contraction

questions.text:
The below image shows a Jugular venous pressure tracing.

What is the false statement regarding this image?
questions.solution:
The JVP is the single most important bedside measurement from which to estimate the volume status.

The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.

The A wave represents right atrial presystolic contraction and occurs just after the electrocardiographic P wave and just before the first heart sound (I).

In this example, the A wave is accentuated and larger than normal due to decreased right ventricular compliance, as also suggested by the right-sided S4 (IV).

The c wave, which occurs as the closed tricuspid valve is pushed into the right atrium during early ventricular systole, interrupts this x descent and is followed by a further descent.

The v wave represents atrial filling (atrial diastole) and occurs during ventricular systole. The height of the v wave is determined by right atrial compliance as well as the volume of blood returning to the right atrium either antegrade from the cavae or retrograde through an incompetent tricuspid valve.

In patients with TR, the v wave is accentuated and the subsequent fall in pressure (y descent) is rapid. With progressive degrees of TR, the v wave merges with the c wave, and the right atrial and jugular vein waveforms become “ventricularized.”

p>Ref.Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 871

questions.text: ORBITAL ABSCESS is which class according to CHANDLER CLASSIFICATION of orbital complication of sinusitis_________
questions.solution:
Chandler's classification is used to categorize orbital complications of sinusitis based on their severity and progression. Class IV involves the highest degree of severity and often requires surgical intervention. Orbital abscesses in this category are characterized by extensive infection and abscess formation within the orbit, posing a significant risk to vision and overall health.

Gower sign showing a patient using his arms to climb up the legs in attempting to get up from the floor.

The Gower’s sign is seen in muscular dystrophy due to weakness of the proximal hip muscles of lower limbs.

Lhermitt’s sign an electric shock like condition by some patients of multiple sclerosis.

Gottron’s sign Thin violaceous papules and plaques on the elbows and knees of patients with dermatomyositis.

Beevor's sign, an upward deflection of the umbilicus on flexion of the neck, is the result of paralysis of the inferior portion of the rectus abdominis muscle, so that the upper fibers predominate, pulling the umbilicus upwards. questions.solution:
In the TNM (Tumor, Node, Metastasis) staging system for cancer, the T stage indicates the extent of the primary tumor. T4b typically refers to advanced local tumor involvement, including invasion into adjacent structures such as the pterygoid plates. In oral cavity cancer staging, T4b signifies extensive local disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with cirrhosis thought secondary to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis presents with altered mental status. All of the following can precipitate hepatic encephalopathy in this type of patient EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Infection is probably the most common, and the most concerning cause of worsening hepatic encephalopathy in a patient with known liver disease.

Dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities are common causes of hepatic encephalopathy.

Dehydration can lead to a contraction alkalosis that causes more ammonium ions (NH4+) to become NH3, which can more easily cross the blood-brain barrier to provoke encephalopathy. Hypokalemia can have the same effect.

Hyperkalemia would be associated with the extracellular shifting of hydrogen ions and have the opposite effect, and therefore is less likely.

Hyponatremia can directly cause altered mental status but can also be associated with dehydration, both of which can worsen encephalopathy. Medication nonadherence is a common cause of worsening hepatic encephalopathy

Ref.Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2632

choices.text: Near total thyroidectomy = total lobectomy + isthmusectomy + subtotal lobectomy

questions.text: What is the dunhill procedure for thyroid operation_________
questions.solution:
The Dunhill procedure is a specific surgical approach used in thyroid surgery. It involves a near total thyroidectomy, which includes the removal of a significant portion of the thyroid gland but leaves a small amount of thyroid tissue to preserve some thyroid function. This procedure typically consists of the removal of both thyroid lobes (total lobectomy), along with the isthmus (isthmusectomy) and a portion of the contralateral thyroid lobe (subtotal lobectomy). It aims to balance the removal of thyroid tissue with the preservation of thyroid function.

Ref : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 860

choices.text: Barium meal and follow-through will show worms scattered in the small bowel
The larval stage in the lungs causes pulmonary symptoms - dry cough, chest pain, dyspnoea and fever - referred to as Loeffler's syndrome

questions.text:
A 18 Yrs old male patient presented to emergency with bouts of colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. Barium meal and follow through is given below.

All are true about this condition except________
questions.solution:
The larval stage in the lungs causes pulmonary symptoms - dry cough, chest pain, dyspnoea and fever - referred to as Loefflerer's syndrome.

The adult worm can grow up to 45 cm long.

The condition being described here is Ascariasis, which is caused by the intestinal roundworm Ascaris lumbricoides. Ascariasis typically presents with symptoms like colicky abdominal pain and vomiting due to intestinal obstruction caused by a mass of worms.

The other statements are true about Ascariasis:

  1. A) Barium meal and follow-through will show worms scattered in the small bowel. This is a characteristic radiological finding in Ascariasis.
  2. B) The larval stage in the lungs causes pulmonary symptoms - dry cough, chest pain, dyspnea, and fever - referred to as Loeffler’s syndrome. This is known as Loeffler's syndrome, a common manifestation of Ascariasis when larvae migrate through the lungs.
  3. C) Conservative management with anthelmintics is the first line of treatment even in obstruction. Anthelmintic medications are typically the first-line treatment for Ascariasis, and they are effective in resolving the infection, even in cases of intestinal obstruction.

Surgery is generally considered when there are complications such as perforation, severe obstruction, or if conservative treatment fails. It is not the first resort for Ascariasis but rather a last resort in specific situations.

Ref : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 70 ,71

questions.text:
Assertion: The myogenic mechanism helps maintain constant renal blood flow by responding to changes in arterial pressure.

Reasoning: The myogenic mechanism involves constriction of afferent arterioles in response to an increase in arterial pressure
questions.solution:
The myogenic mechanism is an important component of renal autoregulation, which helps to maintain a constant renal blood flow despite changes in arterial pressure. This mechanism involves the contraction or relaxation of the smooth muscle cells in the walls of the afferent arterioles in response to changes in stretch or pressure. An increase in arterial pressure leads to an increase in stretch or pressure in the afferent arterioles, which triggers the myogenic response and causes vasoconstriction of the arterioles, thereby reducing renal blood flow.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page 317

questions.text: Maple Syrup Urine Disease Type 1B can result from mutations in the genes that encode
questions.solution:
The mutation in the gene encoding E1 beta results in Maple Syrup Urine Disease Type 1B. This mutation affects the functionality of the BCKD complex, leading to the impaired breakdown of branched-chain amino acids and the accumulation of toxic byproducts in the body.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is a rare inherited metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to break down certain amino acids, specifically leucine, isoleucine, and valine. These amino acids are typically obtained from the diet and are crucial for normal growth and development. In MSUD, a defect in the metabolism of these amino acids leads to their accumulation in the blood, urine, and other bodily fluids, causing a characteristic sweet odor in the urine, sweat, and earwax.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition - Page 309-310.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the antipsychotic drug aripiprazole is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Aripiprazole

This atypical antipsychotic is unique in being a partial agonist at D2 and 5-HT1A receptor, but an antagonist at the 5-HT2 receptor.

Extrapyramidal side effects, hyperprolactinemia and hypotension are not significant. Little tendency to weight gain and rise in blood sugar has been noted. A moderate prolongation of QTc interval occurs at higher doses. Frequent side effects are nausea, dyspepsia, constipation and light-headedness, but not antimuscarinic effects.

questions.text: A 42-yr old explorer complains of fever and persistent cough. On general examination, hilar lymphadenopathy is observed. His chest X-ray shows nodular infiltrates. An image from his lung biopsy stained with silver stain is shown below. Identify the causative organism.

Image shows Histoplasma capsulatum yeast forms filling phagocytes in the lung of a patient with disseminated histoplasmosis; inset shows high-power detail of pear-shaped, thin-based budding yeasts.

The clinical presentations and morphologic lesions of histoplasmosis include (1) a self-limited and often latent primary pulmonary involvement, which may result in coin lesions on chest radiography; (2) chronic, progressive, secondary lung disease, which is localized to the lung apices and causes cough, fever, and night sweats.

choices.text: In solution glucose is dextrorotatory, so glucose is called dextrose.

In a solution it gives a mixture of alpha-glucopyranose (62%) and beta-glucopyranose(38%)

questions.text: All of the following sentences are true about sugar(glucose) except?
questions.solution:
The orientation of the __H and __OH groups around the carbon atom adjacent to the terminal alcohol carbon (carbon 5 in glucose) determines whether the sugar belongs to the D or L series.

The presence of an asymmetric carbon atom also confers optical activity on the compound. When a beam of plane polarized light is passed through a solution of an optical isomer, it rotates either to the right, dextrorotatory (+), or to the left, levorotatory (−).

In solution, glucose is dextrorotatory, and glucose solutions are sometimes known as dextrose.

The ring structures of monosaccharides are similar to the ring structures of either pyran (a six-membered ring) or furan (a five membered ring). For glucose in solution, more than 99% is in the pyranose form.

The ring structure of an aldose is a hemiacetal, since it is formed by a reaction between an aldehyde and an alcohol group. Similarly, the ring structure of a ketose is a hemiketal. Crystalline glucose is α-d-glucopyranose.

The cyclic structure is retained in the solution, but isomerism occurs about position 1, the carbonyl or anomeric carbon atom, to give a mixture of α-glucopyranose (38%) and

β-glucopyranose (62%).

Reference:- Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition - Page 153-154

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ferroptosis?
questions.solution:

Option A: The overall effect in ferroptosis is the loss of plasma membrane permeability, which ultimately leads to cell death resembling necrosis.

Option C: Ferroptosis has been linked to cell death in a variety of human pathologies, including cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and stroke.

questions.text: A 50 year old postmenopausal female was given parenteral bisphosphonate for osteoporosis as slow IV infusion. Later she developed serious thrombophlebitis of veins. Which of the following agents was responsible for the side effect?
questions.solution:
Pamidronate is a second generation potent bisphosphonate which is administered only by IV infusion. It is used in Paget's disease, hypercalcaemia of malignancy and in bony metastases.

Adverse effects are thrombophlebitis of veins, bone pain, fever and leukopenia. A flu-like reaction may occur initially due to cytokine release.

For hypercalcaemia, zoledronate is more effective, faster acting than pamidronate and therefore the drug of choice now. Another advantage is that it can be infused over 15 min (because of less venous irritation), whereas pamidronate needs 2-4 hours. Flu-like symptoms due to cytokine release attend the IV infusion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p371

questions.text: A 2 month old infant was admitted with diagnosis of Staphylococcus aureus omphalitis. APGAR score at birth was normal. Laboratory reports showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia and raised CRP levels. Patient improved with antibiotic treatment. 2 months later, she was re-admitted with cellulitis and marked neutrophilia, which was resolved with antibiotics. On further follow-up of recurrent infections, a mutation in the beta chain of CD 11/CD 18 integrins was found. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
It is a case of leukocyte adhesion deficiency - 1 (LAD-1). These patients have a defect in the biosynthesis of the β2 chain shared by the integrins LFA-1 and Mac-1. It results in a failure of leukocyte adhesion to endothelium, preventing the cells from migrating into tissues and making patients prone to bacterial infections, which are often recurrent and frequently life threatening.

Other options: Other diseases are caused due to defects in innate immunity and their defects are given in the following table.

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 241 Table 6.12

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented to the paediatric OPD and was diagnosed with having pituitary dwarfism unresponsive to GH therapy. Later he was put on mecasermin rinfabate. What is the most important side effect to look for?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic Uses

Mecasermin is FDA-approved for patients with impaired growth secondary to mutations in the GH receptor or postreceptor signaling pathway.

In patients with impaired growth secondary to GH deficiency or with idiopathic short stature, mecasermin stimulates linear growth but is less effective than conventional therapy using recombinant GH.

Adverse Effects:

Side effects of mecasermin include hypoglycemia and lipohypertrophy. To diminish the frequency of hypoglycaemia mecasermin should be administered shortly before or after a meal or snack.

Lymphoid tissue hypertrophy, including enlarged tonsils, is also seen and may require surgical intervention. Other adverse effects are similar to those associated with GH therapy.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13the p778

questions.text: A 72-year-old male who was diagnosed to be a severely hypertensive patient developed a stroke which led to increased intracranial pressure, which on examination was found to be more than mean blood arterial pressure (MBAP). This condition will cause cerebral ischemia, which will trigger __________ reflex, causing hypertension with decreasing heart rate due to stimulation of _________ receptors along with ulcers and irregular breathing.
questions.solution:
When intracranial pressure (ICP) increases more than mean arterial blood pressure (MABP), it causes cerebral ischemia. This activates the sympathetic nervous system, leading to hypertension, which acts on baroreceptors on the aortic arch and activates the parasympathetic nervous system, leading to a decrease in heart rate due to its action on muscarinic receptors. This hypertension also increases pressure on the respiratory center, causing irregular breathing. This complete reflex is known as Cushing's reflex.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, pg. 585-590

choices.text: N-formylmethionine is the precursor of eukaryotic polypeptide synthesis
Eukaryotic ribosomes are smaller than prokaryotic
Identification of 5' cap of mRNA by eIF4E is the rate limiting step of protein synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Identification of 5' cap of mRNA by IF4E is the rate limiting step

Rate limiting steps of Protein Translation are:

eIF 2

eIF4F (specifically saying 4E of 4 F complex)

Option a: Methionine is the first amino acid in eukaryotic protein synthesis

Option b: The eukaryotic ribosome is bigger than the prokaryotic ribosome

Option d: Elongation Factor 2 is associated with hydrolysis of GTP not ATP.

The Regulation of eIF-4E Controls the Rate of Initiation

The 4F complex is particularly important in controlling the rate of protein translation. As described above, 4F is a complex consisting of 4E, which binds to the m7G cap structure at the 5′ end of the mRNA, and 4G, which serves as a scaffolding protein.

In addition to binding 4E, 4G binds to eIF-3, which links the complex to the 40S ribosomal subunit. It also binds 4A and 4B, the ATPase-helicase complex that helps unwind the RNA.

4E is responsible for recognition of the mRNA cap structure, a rate-limiting step in translation.

questions.text: According to the mechanisms shown in the figure, which of the site correctly shows the mechanism of erenumab:
questions.solution:
Erenumab is a monoclonal antibody against CGRP receptors. It is approved for the prophylaxis of migraine.

  • Drug B is likely to be a 'ditan' (e.g. lasmiditan). These drugs act by stimulating 5HT1F that decreases the release of CGRP.
  • Drug A is a 5HT1B/1D agonist like sumatriptan
  • Drug D is a beta blocker like propranolol.

CGRP is a potent vasodilatory and proinflammatory neuropeptide. Along these lines, a new class of migraine drugs has been developed that blocks signaling by CGRP. These include the small-molecule CGRP receptor antagonist drug rimegepant, and the CGRP-blocking monoclonal antibodies erenumab, fremanezumab, and galcanezumab.

questions.text: A 30-year old woman was diagnosed with SLE 5 years back. On her recent visit to the rheumatologist, she was found to have proteinuria and hematuria. Light microscopic image of a glomerulus from her renal biopsy is shown. Identify the type of lupus nephritis shown.
questions.solution:
Option C: Image shows a glomerulus with several 'wire loop' lesions representing extensive subendothelial deposits of immune complexes, in a patient with lupus nephritis.

In class-IV nephritis, involved glomeruli show proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and epithelial cells, with the latter producing cellular crescents that fill the Bowman's space.. Subendothelial immune complex deposits may cause circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, forming 'wire loop' structures on light microscopy.

Option A: Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I) is characterized by immune complex deposition in the mesangium, but without structural changes.

Option B: Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II) is characterized by mesangial cell proliferation, often accompanied by accumulation of mesangial matrix, and granular mesangial deposits of immunoglobulin and complement without involvement of glomerular capillaries.

Option D: Membranous lupus nephritis (class V) is characterized by diffuse thickening of the capillary walls due to deposition of subepithelial immune complexes. The immune complexes are usually accompanied by increased production of basement membrane- like material.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 226-227

questions.text: All of the following are causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis EXCEPT

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly represent the increasing order of potency of inhalational anesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Two important properties of an inhalational agent are its minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) and blood gas partition coefficient.

  • Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC): It is the minimum concentration of an inhalational agent required in the alveoli to produce unresponsiveness to skin incision in 50% of the patients. It is the measure of potency of an agent. Greater is the MAC, lesser is the potency.
  • Nitrous oxide is a gas with maximum MAC and thus least potency. Its MAC is 104% i.e. even with pure (100%) nitric oxide alone, we cannot get complete anesthesia. This is thus, not a complete anaesthetic agent.
  • Methoxyflurane is the most potent agent (having least MAC).

questions.text: A 48-yr old man complains of dysphagia and postprandial epigastric pain for many years. An image from a biopsy taken from a few cm above the GE junction is shown below. What is the criteria to classify the condition as 'long segment'?

questions.text:
Find the true statements from below:
1.Cytoskeletal filaments are microfilaments, intermediate filaments and microtubules; out of these, the microtubules have a diameter of 25 nm and are made up of tubulin.
2.Microtubules are polar with assembly predominating at the (+) end and disassembly predominating at the (-) end.

4.Colchicine and vinblastine prevent microtubule assembly.

Which statements are true?
questions.solution:
Cytoskeleton is an intracellular system of fibers, which maintains the structural integrity of the cell and allows appropriate change in cell shape for cell mobility and participation of the cell in various physiological activities. It consists of microfilaments, microtubules and intermediate filaments. These cytoskeletal elements are made up of different cell proteins

questions.text: The half-life of dobutamine is:
questions.solution:
Dobutamine is an inotropic drug which has onset of action in 1-2 min.

Peak action = 1-10 min.

Duration of action = < 10 min.

Half life = 2 min.

Dobutamine has a t1/2 of about 2 min; the major metabolites are conjugates of dobutamine and 3-O-methyl dobutamine. The onset of effect is rapid. Steady-state concentrations generally are achieved within 10 min of initiation of the infusion by calibrated infusion pump.

The rate of infusion required to increase cardiac output typically is between 2.5 and 10 μg/kg per min, although higher infusion rates occasionally are required. The rate and duration of the infusion are determined by the clinical and hemodynamic responses of the patient.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female working in an agricultural field was attacked by a honey bee. After some time, she felt itchy all over her body, had difficulty in breathing, was unable to drink water, was nauseated, and lost consciousness. She was admitted to the Emergency department. Blood smear was taken for diagnosis, and the smear showed the following findings.
questions.solution:
A is a basophil, and B is a mast cell. Both are involved in allergic reactions and anaphylaxis, and both release histamine, bradykinin, serotonin, and heparin. Basophils are found in circulation, while mast cells are found in tissues and immediately outside capillaries and nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following is the source of all carbon in cholesterol?
questions.solution:
CHOLESTEROL IS BIOSYNTHESIZED FROM ACETYL-CoA

A little more than half the cholesterol of the body arises by synthesis (about 700 mg/d), and the remainder is provided by the average diet. The liver and intestine account for approximately 10% each of total synthesis in humans. Virtually all tissues containing nucleated cells are capable of cholesterol synthesis, which occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and the cytosolic compartments.

Acetyl-CoA Is the Source of All Carbon Atoms in Cholesterol

Cholesterol is a 27-carbon compound consisting of 4 rings and a side chain. It is synthesized from acetyl CoA by a lengthy pathway that may be divided into five steps:

(1) synthesis of mevalonate from acetyl-CoA ;

(2) formation of isoprenoid units from mevalonate by loss of CO2 ;

(3) condensation of six isoprenoid units form squalene ;

(4) cyclization of squalene give rise to the parent steroid, lanosterol;

(5) formation of cholesterol from lanosterol .

Reference : Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition - Page 267

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for the treatment of advanced stages of endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Pembrolizumab is a humanized monoclonal IgG4-κ isotype antibody that blocks interaction between PD-1 and its ligands.

The FDA has extended the approval for pembrolizumab to any cancer with mismatch repair (MMR) deficiency or high microsatellite instability (MSI-H). The defects in DNA repair lead to a higher mutation load and increased generation of mutant protein antigen by cancer cells that can activate the immune system.

This first cancer tissue-agnostic approval extends immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment to subsets of patients with hereditary colorectal cancer due to Lynch syndrome (MSI-H) and up to 20% of patients with sporadic colon cancer. The frequency is less in endometrial, ovarian and pancreatic cancers and will require testing of each patient's tumor to assess suitability of the treatment.

questions.text: Wenckebach phenomenon is seen in;
questions.solution:
In Mobitz type 1 of the second-degree heart block, the PR interval is prolonged progressively in a repeated sequence of beats until a QRS complex (ventricular beat) is dropped. The PR interval following the dropped beat is usually normal, but in subsequent beats, the PR interval progressively prolongs until the next beat is dropped, which is known as the Wenckebach phenomenon.

questions.text: Apoproteins are important structures in human metabolism. Which of the following statements about apoproteins is false:
questions.solution:
Apoprotein A-II and apo C-III inhibits lipoprotein lipase.

Apoprotein C-II activates lipoprotein lipase.

Apolipoproteins carry out several roles:

(1) They can form part of the structure of the lipoprotein, for example, apo B;

(2) They are enzyme cofactors, for example, C-II for lipoprotein lipase, A-I for lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase, or

(3) Enzyme inhibitors, for example, apo A-II and apo C-III for lipoprotein lipase, apo C-I for cholesteryl ester transfer protein; and

(4)They act as ligands for interaction with lipoprotein receptors in tissues, for example, apo B-100 and apo E for the LDL receptor, apo E for the LDL-receptor-related protein-1 (LRP-1), which has been identified as the remnant receptor, and apo A-I for the HDL receptor.

(5)The functions of apo A-IV and apo D, however, are not yet clearly defined, although apo D is believed to be an important factor in human neurodegenerative disorders.

questions.text: Based on the mechanism of action provided in the below image Drug E is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Ezogabine Mechanisms of Action Ezogabine is a first-in-class K+ channel opener. It is also known as retigabine. Ezogabine enhances transmembrane K+ currents mediated by the KCNQ family of ion channels.

Through its activation of the KCNQ channels, ezogabine may stabilize the resting membrane potential and reduce neuronal excitability.

Therapeutic uses:

Ezogabine was approved in the U.S. as an adjunctive treatment for focal-onset seizures in patients aged 18 years and older with inadequate response to alternative ASDs and for whom the benefits outweigh the risk of retinal abnormalities and potential visual acuity deficits.
