questions.text: A 60-year-old woman complains of progressive hoarseness, shortness of breath, and stridor for the past 4 weeks. On physical examination, she has a firm, large, tender mass involving the entire right lobe of thyroid. CT scan shows extension of this mass posterior to the trachea and into the upper mediastinum. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass is done, and microscopically shows pleomorphic spindle cells. Pulmonary metastases are identified on a chest radiograph. Which of the following is not true regarding this neoplasm?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a thyroid neoplasm with several features that suggest it is anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, a highly aggressive neoplasm of thyroid follicular epithelium. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is known for its rapid growth and propensity to invade surrounding structures, which is consistent with the clinical findings in this case.

In contrast to well-differentiated thyroid carcinomas, anaplastic thyroid carcinomas typically do not produce thyroglobulin. Instead, they contain pleomorphic spindle cells. Additionally, these tumors often occur de novo and are not associated with a past history of well-differentiated thyroid neoplasms, which distinguishes them from differentiated thyroid cancers.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease 10th ed. Pg 1090-1091

questions.text: The perinuclear hof seen in plasma cells is due to?

questions.text: A 10-year old girl presented with hydrocephalus. Imaging studies showed a mass in posterior fossa . The mass was surgically removed, histologic image of which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ependymomas are tumors that most often arise in proximity to the ependyma-lined ventricular system, including the obliterated central canal of the spinal cord. Despite their similar morphologic appearance, ependymomas occurring at different sites (supratentorial, posterior fossa, spinal) tend to be associated with distinct sets of driver mutations.

As seen in the image, ependymomas are composed of cells with fibrillary processes that contain regular, round to oval nuclei with granular chromatin. Tumor cells may form glandlike round or elongated structures (rosettes, canals) that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into a lumen; more frequently present are perivascular pseudorosettes in which there is a perivascular nuclear-free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the marked muscle?

questions.text: Which of the following features of HPV associated SCC differentiates it from non-HPV associated SCC?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus (HPV)-associated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the head and neck region, particularly in the oropharynx (tonsils and base of tongue), is known to have distinct clinical and pathological features when compared to non-HPV-associated SCC.

One of the key features that differentiates HPV-associated SCC from non-HPV-associated SCC is that HPV-associated SCC often presents as "non-keratinizing" SCC. This means that the tumor lacks the characteristic keratin pearls seen in non-HPV-associated SCC. Instead, HPV-associated SCC tends to have a basaloid or poorly differentiated appearance under the microscope.

questions.text: In the water deprivation test for classification of diabetes insipidus, what is the interpretation when final urinary osmolality before arginine vasopressin challenge is less than plasma osmolality, and following arginine vasopressin, there is 10% rise in urine osmolality?
questions.solution:
In the water deprivation test, various parameters are monitored to classify the type of diabetes insipidus (DI) a patient may have. DI is characterized by excessive thirst and urination due to the inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine effectively. The test helps distinguish between central DI (neurogenic) and nephrogenic DI.

When the final urinary osmolality before arginine vasopressin challenge is less than plasma osmolality, it suggests that the kidneys are unable to concentrate urine properly.

Following arginine vasopressin administration, a 10% or less rise in urine osmolality indicates that the kidneys are not responding to the vasopressin signal as they should.

These findings are consistent with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), which is characterized by a lack of response to vasopressin due to a defect in the renal tubules. In central DI, the kidneys are usually able to concentrate urine appropriately in response to vasopressin.

Reference: Henry's clinical diagnosis and management by laboratory methods, 24th ed. Pg 393

questions.text: Which of the following would be best for offering HIV testing and counseling services in a center with a high client load?

F-ICTCs have been set up below the block levels at 24 x 7 PHC, etc. Staff of the existing health facilities are trained in counseling and testing services of HIV. The HIV service delivery is ensured with logistic support from DAC.

questions.text: According to the Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS), which one of the following is associated with an increased risk of converting from ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS) is a multicenter randomized clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of topical ocular hypotensive medications in preventing or delaying the development of primary open angle glaucoma in subjects with ocular hypertension. This study also identified baseline demographic and clinical features that predicted which participants were more likely to progress to primary open angle glaucoma. Enrolled patients were randomized to observation or treatment with topical glaucoma medications to lower IOP by 20% and maintain IOP less than or equal to 24 mm Hg. After 5 years of follow-up, 4.4% of treated patients developed glaucoma compared with 9.5% in the untreated observation group. Higher IOP, reduced central corneal thickness, increased cup-disc ratio, older age, and higher pattern standard deviation on visual field testing were identified as significant risk factors for the development of primary open angle glaucoma in patients with ocular hypertension. Diabetes mellitus was a negative risk factor.

Reference: Kanski's book of clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number347

questions.text:

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the conjunctiva

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a history of several days of redness in a single sector of her left eye, as demonstrated in the figure. She also has moderately deep pain of the involved eye. She denies foreign-body sensation. She has had no previous eye problems. On examination, most of the dilated vessels are radial and can be moved with a cotton tip applicator. These vessels blanch with instillation of topical phenylephrine. The overlying conjunctiva also has some dilated vessels, but it's epithelial surface is normal. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
In this patient the inflammation appears to be in the episcleral tissues, so she has episcleritis. Episcleritis is classified as simple or nodular. Simple episcleritis usually presents as a sector of inflammation, sparing most of the remaining episclera. In nodular episcleritis, the inflammation is accompanied by a mobile nodule. In scleritis, the deeper scleral vessels are more involved than the episclera, so the dilated vessels show a crisscross pattern and are not mobile. A pinguecula may become inflamed but usually is not associated with pain other than foreign-body sensation. Pinguecula are typically located in the nasal or temporal bulbar conjunctiva, whereas the inflamed tissue in this case is in an oblique meridian. A squamous cell carcinoma often has dilated feeder vessels, but there is usually no pain, and the conjunctival epithelium appears abnormal.

Reference: Kanski's book of clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number292

A married couple, 25 years old, sleeping in the same room

questions.text: In which of the following cases is overcrowding present?
questions.solution:
Overcrowding refers to the situation in which more people are living within a single dwelling than there is space for, so that movement is restricted, privacy secluded, hygiene impossible, rest and sleep difficult. The accepted standards with respect to overcrowding are as below :

Persons Per Room:

  • 1 room - 2 persons
  • 2 rooms - 3 persons
  • 3 rooms - 5 persons
  • 4 rooms - 7 persons
  • 5 or more rooms - 10 persons (add 2 for each additional room)

Floor Space:

  • 110 sq.ft. (11 sq. m.) or more - 2 persons
  • 90-100 sq.ft. (9-10 sq. m.) - 1.5 persons
  • 70-90 sq.ft. (7-9 sq. m.) - 1 person
  • 50-70 sq.ft. (5-7 sq. m.) - 0.5 person
  • Under 50 sq.ft. (5 sq. m.) - Not suitable for habitation
  • Babies under 12 months are not counted; children between 1 to 10 years are counted as half a unit.

Sex Separation:

  • Overcrowding exists if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband and wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 812

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most commonly associated with the below image?
questions.solution:
Above image is of Orbital Floor fracture aka blow out fracture.

A common site of orbital floor fractures is the thin bony encasement of the infraorbital nerve in the orbital floor. Infraorbital nerve trauma leads to decreased sensation in the midface and is observed frequently. Orbital cellulitis is a rare occurrence in this setting. Enophthalmos may develop in larger fractures as orbital edema decreases; however, it usually takes longer than 24 hours for this to become evident. Similarly, the diplopia occurring after a floor fracture may result from entrapment or contusion of the muscle. In either case, complete resolution would be rare within 24 hours.

Reference: Kanski's book of clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number 894

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the prevalence of features of vitamin A deficiency in the population at risk (6 months to 6 years) in 4 communities. In which of the following communities is xerophthalmia a public health problem?
questions.solution:
The formulation of an effective intervention programme for prevention of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) begins with the characterization of the problem. This is done by population surveys employing both clinical and biochemical criteria. These surveys (prevalence surveys) are done on preschool children (6 months to 6 years) who are at special risk.

Bitot's spots are a clinical sign of vitamin A deficiency and are considered a form of xerophthalmia. The presence of Bitot's spots suggests a deficiency in vitamin A, which is essential for maintaining healthy eyesight. Bitot's spots are one of the clinical criteria used to assess the prevalence of vitamin A deficiency in a population, as recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, pages 670 and 673

choices.text: More expensive than a standard tuberculin skin test (TST)
Affected by HIV and low CD4 count

questions.text: All of the following are true about the interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) test for detection of TB infection except:
questions.solution:
IGRA tests are typically more expensive than the traditional Tuberculin Skin Test (TST), also known as the Mantoux test. IGRA involves laboratory processing and requires specialized equipment, which adds to its cost.

IGRA results can be affected by conditions that weaken the immune system, such as HIV infection and low CD4 cell counts. In individuals with compromised immune systems, IGRA may yield false-negative results.

IGRA is designed to have high specificity, even in individuals who have been vaccinated with BCG. BCG vaccination can cause false-positive results with the Tuberculin Skin Test (TST), but IGRA is less likely to be affected by BCG vaccination.

IGRA tests require laboratory facilities and infrastructure for sample processing and analysis. Unlike the TST, which can be administered at the point of care, IGRA tests involve more sophisticated laboratory procedures.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 435

questions.solution:

Hydroxyapatite has demonstrated excellent biocompatibility and the use of cartilage is not always required with this allograft material; however, it is probably prudent to use cartilage even in these cases.

(b) individuals aged more than 6 months with one of the several chronic medical conditions;

(c) healthy young adults between age 15-49 years (option D),

(d) healthy children;

(e) healthy adults between age 49-65 years; and

questions.solution:
Nonallergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome (NARES) is characterized by the presence of nasal eosinophilia in subjects who are often middle-aged with perennial symptoms of sneezing paroxysms, nasal itching, rhinorrhoea and, occasionally, loss of sense of smell. However, they lack evidence of allergic disease as determined by skin tests and IgE levels. Some may represent an early stage of aspirin idiosyncrasy. questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding rotavirus diarrhea in children?
questions.solution:
The universal occurrence of rotavirus infections shows that clean water supplies and good hygiene are unlikely to have a substantial effect on virus transmission.

The rotavirus, first discovered in 1973, has emerged as the leading cause of severe, dehydrating diarrhea in children aged < 5 years globally, with an estimate of more than 25 million out-patient visits and more than 2 million hospitalizations attributable to rotavirus infections each year (option A).

Rotavirus vaccines are now included in the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) and are given by the oral route at 6, 10 and 14 weeks of age (option C).

Rotavirus reinfection is common, although the primary infection is usually the most significant clinically (option D).

This condition is still frequently referred to as Pott’s puffy tumour, following its description by Sir Percival Pott in 1760. questions.text: What is the frequency of administration of benzathine penicillin for primary prevention of rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:

This is achieved by a single dose of IM benzathine penicillin (1.2 million IU for adults and 600,000 IU for children) or oral penicillin for 10 days.

Secondary prophylaxis is given to patients after the first attack of RF and is given for every 3 weeks.

questions.text: In which carcinoma of ca nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses distant metastasis is more common?
questions.solution:
Distant metastases at the time of presentation are very unusual. They develop in 18 percent of patients with adenocarcinomas, in contrast to just 10 percent of those with squamous cell carcinomas. When found, they are usually associated with local recurrence. The most common sites for metastases are bone, brain, liver, lung and skin.

questions.text: If no contraindications are present, fibrinolysis for ST-elevation myocardial infarction should be administered within how many minutes of presentation?
questions.solution:
If no contraindications are present, fibrinolytic therapy should ideally be initiated within 30 minutes of presentation (i.e., door-to-needle time ≤30 minutes).

The principal goal of fibrinolysis is prompt restoration of full coronary arterial patency. The fibrinolytic agents tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), streptokinase, tenecteplase (TNK), and reteplase (rPA) have been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for IV use in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction.

These drugs all act by promoting the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, which subsequently lyses fibrin thrombi. Although considerable emphasis was first placed on a distinction between more fibrin-specific agents, such as tPA, and non-fibrin-specific agents, such as streptokinase, it is now recognized that these differences are only relative, as some degree of systemic fibrinolysis occurs with the former agents. TNK and rPA are referred to as bolus fibrinolytics since their administration does not require a prolonged IV infusion.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 1829

questions.text: All of the following are true about the post-exposure management of a dog/cat bite wound except:
questions.solution:
If the wound has to be sutured, RIG must first be infiltrated in and around the wound before suturing

A bite by a provoked animal does not mean that the animal is not rabid. Therefore, a provoked dog bite should also be managed as exposure and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be started immediately (option A).

Washing of wounds is desirable up to 15 minutes and should be carried out as soon as possible with soap and water (option B).

As rabies is a nearly 100% fatal disease, there is no contraindication to post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Moreover, the rabies vaccine does not have any adverse effect on pregnant women, course of pregnancy, fetus or lactating mother (option D).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition - Page no 612

questions.text: A 38 year old female patient ha breathlessness even with mild exertion (grade 3).She has severe mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation .Along with increased ventricular rate ,clots in the left atrium are seen. Which of the following should not be done?
questions.solution:
In atrial fibrillation, the clots that are formed are kept retained in the left atrium due to twitching activity of the atria.

Moreover, the MS also reduces the chance of clot embolization.Hence in case cardioversion is done,the normal sinus rhythm ensues and the proper contraction of atria allows dislodgement of clot from the area.

The percutaneous balloon valvotomy procedure dilates the mitral annulus, relieves the annulus and chances of clot embolization via a bigger orifice increased.

Usually cardioversion should be undertaken after the patient has had at least 3 consecutive weeks of anticoagulant treatment to a therapeutic INR.

If cardioversion is indicated more urgently, then intravenous heparin should be provided and TEE performed to exclude the presence of LA thrombus before the procedure.

In the presence of the LA thrombus,if cardioversion is performed it can dislodge the thrombus and can lead to thromboembolism.

Conversion to sinus rhythm is rarely successful or sustained in patients with severe MS, particularly those in whom the LA is significantly enlarged or in whom AF has been present for >1 year, conditions that favor the development of an LA myopathy

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 1994

questions.text: Match the following Named sign with its site seen in the patient of Aortic regurgitation.
questions.solution:
A rapidly rising 'water-hammer' pulse, which collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole (Corrigan's pulse), and capillary pulsations,

An alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail (Quincke's pulse), are characteristic of chronic severe AR.

A booming 'pistol-shot' sound can be heard over the femoral arteries (Traube's sign)

A to-and-fro murmur (Duroziez's sign) is audible if the femoral artery is lightly compressed with a stethoscope.

The arterial pulse pressure is widened as a result of both systolic hypertension and a lowering of the diastolic pressure. The measurement of arterial diastolic pressure with a sphygmomanometer may be complicated by the fact that systolic sounds are frequently heard with the cuff completely deflated.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man has come for his full body check up. He is otherwise healthy. His family history is notable for high cholesterol in his mother and maternal grandfather. Physical examination shows tendon xanthomas. A fasting lipid panel is notable for LDL level of 387 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely genetic disorder affecting this individual?
questions.solution:
FH is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptor. In this condition, there is a decrease in LDL receptor function, leading to reduced clearance of LDL cholesterol from the circulation. This results in very high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood.

FH is one of the most common inherited causes of high cholesterol.

In heterozygous FH, which is more common, LDL cholesterol levels typically range from 200 to 400 mg/dL.

In homozygous FH, LDL receptor function is severely impaired, leading to LDL cholesterol levels of 400 to over 1000 mg/dL.

Individuals with FH may develop tendon xanthomas, which are fatty deposits in tendons.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 3139

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with known sickle cell anemia is admitted to the ICU with diffuse body pain, shortness of breath, fever, and cough. On examination, his blood pressure and heart rate are elevated, and he is in obvious pain and respiratory discomfort. His room air SaO2 is 83%. His chest radiograph shows bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates. This is his third similar episode in the last 12 months. All of the statements regarding his condition are true EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing sickle cell acute chest syndrome, which is characterized by chest pain, respiratory symptoms, and radiographic evidence of lung infiltrates, s/o acute chest syndrome.

Chronic therapy with oral hydroxyurea should be considered for patients with severe symptoms.

Hematocrit should be maintained, and transfusion is indicated to maintain a hematocrit above 30% and in case of severe oxygen desaturation.

Daily sildenafil is not recommended as it has shown adverse effects and hasn't demonstrated significant benefits in treating acute chest syndrome in sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes with back pain. His creatinine was 1.1 mg/dL, albumin 3.9 g/dL, and serum calcium 10.1 mg/dL. A bone marrow biopsy demonstrated 20% clonal plasma cells and serum monoclonal IgA was 15g/L. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient presents with back pain, high serum calcium, elevated serum IgA, and a bone marrow biopsy demonstrating clonal plasma cells. These findings are suggestive of multiple myeloma, a malignancy of plasma cells.

The next best step in the management of this patient is to perform a Positron Emission Tomography-CT (PET-CT) scan.

A PET-CT scan is used to determine the extent of the disease, identify areas of bone involvement, and assess for the presence of any lytic bone lesions, which are characteristic of multiple myeloma. It helps in staging the disease and guiding further management.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 871

questions.text: All of the following statements about Atrial Myxomas are true, except?
questions.solution:
Atrial myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumors in adults. While they may produce a variety of symptoms and signs, including constitutional symptoms like fever, weight loss, and Raynaud's phenomenon, they are not typically associated with a "tumor plop" sound in systole. Instead, a "tumor plop" is often heard in early or mid-diastole and is thought to result from the impact of the tumor against the mitral valve or ventricular wall.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 2026
